stimulusHtml:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

 

Athlete’s foot is a fungal infection that usually begins between a person’s toes. Consider a study designed to investigate the following claim.

A disinfectant foot ointment is effective in curing athlete’s foot.

Two designs are proposed for the study.

Method A Method B
Randomly select 110 people from the population of people who have athlete’s foot to use the disinfectant foot ointment each day and observe the number of people cured after two weeks. Obtain 110 volunteers from the population of people who have athlete’s foot. Randomly assign 80 of the volunteers to use the disinfectant foot ointment each day. Assign the remaining 30 volunteers to use a placebo each day. Observe the number of people cured in each group after two weeks.

(a) Give an example of what people assigned to use a placebo in Method B might be asked to use instead of the disinfectant foot ointment. Explain the benefit of the placebo in the context of the study.

(b) For which method can the results of the study be generalized to all people who have athlete’s foot? Explain, in the context of the study, the characteristic of the method that allows for this generalization.

A researcher conducted the study described in Method B and estimated the difference in the proportions of people similar to those in the study who would be cured by the two treatments. Assume all conditions for inference were met. The resulting 90 percent confidence interval (Disinfectant Foot Ointment minus Placebo) is 0.20±0.16.

(c) Does the 90 percent confidence interval provide evidence to support the claim? Justify your answer.
(d) Suppose that the researcher instead decided to compute a 98 percent confidence interval for the same sample data. Would this change impact your answer in part (c)? Explain your reasoning.

The researcher plans to randomly select people from the study, one at a time and without replacement, to be interviewed. The interviews will continue until 10 people who had received the disinfectant foot ointment are interviewed. Let the random variable B represent the total number of people interviewed.

(e) Explain, in the context of the study, why the random variable B does not follow a binomial distribution.
